constructs.name: compulsive_context_switching
constructs.description: Frequency and intensity of involuntary shifting attention between tasks, apps, or activities despite intention to focus

constructs.name: urge_to_switch
constructs.description: Momentary craving or impulse to check something else, shift tasks, or seek new stimuli

constructs.name: task_engagement
constructs.description: Degree of absorption, flow, and sustained attention in current task

constructs.name: current_emotional_state
constructs.description: Present mood valence and arousal, including stress, anxiety, boredom, or frustration

constructs.name: physical_state
constructs.description: Bodily sensations including hunger, caffeine level, physical comfort, and restlessness

constructs.name: metacognitive_awareness
constructs.description: Real-time awareness of one's own attention state and switching behavior; mindfulness of when urges arise

constructs.name: impulse_control_capacity
constructs.description: Available self-regulation resources to resist impulses; executive function capacity that depletes through the day

constructs.name: cognitive_fatigue
constructs.description: Mental exhaustion and reduced cognitive resources from sustained effort or poor recovery

constructs.name: overall_stress_level
constructs.description: Background level of perceived stress from work, life demands, and unfinished tasks

constructs.name: social_connection_need
constructs.description: Craving for social interaction, validation, or fear of missing out on social information

constructs.name: habit_strength
constructs.description: Automaticity and entrenchment of context-switching as a behavioral pattern; reinforced through repetition

constructs.name: sleep_quality
constructs.description: Quality and quantity of sleep from the previous night

constructs.name: notification_exposure
constructs.description: Frequency and intrusiveness of external interruptions from devices, apps, and alerts

constructs.name: environmental_cues
constructs.description: Visual presence and accessibility of distracting devices, browser tabs, or applications

constructs.name: task_difficulty_skill_match
constructs.description: Whether current task difficulty matches skill level - optimal creates flow, mismatch causes boredom or overwhelm

constructs.name: task_intrinsic_interest
constructs.description: Inherent appeal and engaging qualities of the current task independent of external rewards

constructs.name: time_pressure
constructs.description: Perceived urgency and deadline pressure from pending commitments and obligations

constructs.name: trait_impulsivity
constructs.description: Dispositional tendency toward impulsive behavior and difficulty delaying gratification

constructs.name: novelty_seeking_tendency
constructs.description: Trait preference for new stimuli, variety, and stimulation

constructs.name: frustration_tolerance
constructs.description: Dispositional ability to persist through difficulty, boredom, and discomfort without escaping

edges.description: Strong urges to switch directly precipitate switching behavior when not inhibited
High engagement and flow states protect against switching; low engagement creates vulnerability
Awareness of urges and attention state enables conscious choice rather than automatic switching
Notifications can trigger automatic reflexive attention shifts bypassing deliberation
Negative emotions like anxiety, boredom, and frustration increase urge to escape into distraction
Negative emotional states impair concentration and reduce task absorption
Optimal challenge-skill balance creates flow; mismatch causes boredom or overwhelm
Inherently interesting tasks naturally capture and sustain attention
Boring tasks increase craving for more stimulating alternatives
Each notification creates a curiosity-driven urge to check and respond
Visible distractors like open tabs and nearby phone cue conditioned switching urges
Hunger, caffeine crashes, and discomfort worsen mood and increase irritability
Physical discomfort and restlessness reduce capacity for mindful attention
Mental exhaustion depletes self-regulation resources needed to resist urges
Chronic stress accelerates mental exhaustion and depletes cognitive resources
Deadline pressure and urgency contribute to elevated stress levels
Stress increases desire for social support and connection-seeking behavior
Poor sleep leads to impaired cognitive recovery and daytime fatigue
Sleep deprivation directly impairs prefrontal cortex function and self-control
Higher executive control capacity enables resisting switching urges
Low self-control capacity amplifies experienced urge intensity
Mental exhaustion reduces ability to maintain focus and enter flow states
Fatigue impairs meta-awareness and makes automatic behavior more likely
High background stress creates anxious irritable emotional baseline
Poor sleep increases negative affect, irritability, and emotional reactivity
Sleep quality affects physical energy, alertness, and bodily comfort
Unmet social needs create urges to check social media and communications
Strong habits make switching automatic, bypassing conscious deliberation
Entrenched habits create conditioned urges in response to environmental cues
Higher trait impulsivity means lower baseline capacity for impulse control
High novelty seekers experience stronger urges for new stimulation
Higher frustration tolerance enables sustained engagement through difficult or boring periods
Excessive switching leads to guilt, frustration, and self-criticism
Frequent switching depletes cognitive resources and accelerates fatigue
Switching reduces productivity, creating accumulated work and deadline pressure
Each switch reinforces the habitual pattern through neural pathway strengthening
